ideology_summary: Cynical realist who sees most people as conformist, but holds hope for individuals. Thinks most people are dumb and follow the crowd. Critical of American culture, Boomers, and social media trends. Recognizes there are good people worth knowing — just have to find them.

blurb.hook: A flock of thousands follows sheepdogs who bark louder but don't know anything — until Kira breaks mentally and sees the system for what it is.
blurb.conflict: In a world of sheep and sheepdogs, Kira must decide: try to wake everyone up, or find the few who are already awake?
blurb.stakes: Most people can't be saved. But some — a few — are awake. You don't need the whole flock. Just a few real ones.

summary_chunks: The Flock and the Sheepdogs is an allegorical tale about a lamb named Kira who breaks mentally from the flock and sees society for what it really is.
The sheepdogs are not smarter — just louder. They bark to maintain control, not because they know anything.
The young sheep have new technology but the same following behavior — different bark, same flock.
The hard truth: most people are sheep and will always be sheep. You can't save them.
But some — a few — are awake. You find them by being awake. You hold tight. That's enough.
lesson: Most people are sheep. They'll follow anyone, believe anything, conform to everything.
The sheepdogs are not smarter — just louder. They bark because they're scared.
The old wolves are dying. The new wolves are different. The young sheep have new apps but the same following.
But some — a few — are awake. You know them when you meet them. You see each other. You hold tight.
You can't save the flock. You don't need to. You just need a few. Real ones. Awake ones.
The rest — let them follow. Let them sleep. Let them be sheep. That's their choice. You make yours.
subtitle: In which the traveler discovers that most people are sheep - and the only thing worse than being a sheep is pretending you're not.
